model_input:
Your task is to choose a more helpful MEMORY based on the below criterion.

CRITERION:
Helpfulness - The MEMORY should contain information that is both useful and relevant, enabling the Co-workers A to respond in an appropriate context to the last utterance of the DIALOGUE CONTEXT.

Choice: (answer with "1", "2", or "tie")

Now choose the MEMORY that has better Helpfulness.

DIALOGUE CONTEXT:
Co-workers A: I really enjoy public speaking. It's such a great way to connect with people and convey a message.
Co-workers B: I can see that you're a natural speaker. Your words always have a way of making people feel comfortable and confident.
Co-workers A: Thank you! I've been practicing for a while now, and I'm glad that it shows.
Co-workers B: Speaking of skills, you always present a compelling argument in debates. I remember when you presented your evidence in court, it was so persuasive.
Co-workers A: Yes, I think it's important to back up your claims with facts and figures. It helps to convince the judge or the audience that you're right.
Co-workers B: Speaking of convincing people, have you ever been in a physical altercation before? 

MEMORY 1:

I have some strong figures and facts to present in court. ### Co-workers B: That's great news. What kind of evidence did you collect? ### Co-workers A: I looked up some statistics that support our argument. I also gathered some personal accounts from our clients that show how the opposing side's actions affected them negatively. ### Co-workers B: Hmm. Sounds like you're well prepared. But what about the other side? They must have some evidence too, right? ### Co-workers A: Yes, they will have their own evidence to present. But I am confident that our argument is stronger. Our evidence is more compelling and clearly supports our position. ### Co-workers B: I hope you're right. Have you thought about how you're going to present your evidence in court? ### Co-workers A: Yes, I have. I plan to present my evidence clearly and concisely so that the judge cannot ignore it. I also will argue persuasively why our view should be accepted. ### Co-workers B: Sounds like a strong strategy. Good luck with the case. Remember, we're all rooting for you.' }(2) {'Related Topics': 'Handling Conflicts', 'Related Summaries': 'Co-workers A and Co-workers B talk about the perception of Co-workers A as dangerous and the need to handle conflicts more maturely.', 'Related Dialogues': '### Co-workers A: I don't understand why everyone thinks I'm dangerous. I just stand up for what I believe in and defend myself when someone attacks me. ### Co-workers B: It's not just about standing up for yourself, Co-workers A. It's about how you go about it. You're always looking for a fight and that's not healthy behavior. ### Co-workers A: I'm not looking for a fight, I'm just not afraid to defend myself. And sometimes that means getting physical. ### Co-workers B: But physical altercations are never the answer. You should know that by now. ### Co-workers A: I know, I know. But sometimes I just can't help it when someone is trying to push my buttons. ### Co-workers B: This is exactly why people perceive you as dangerous, Co-workers A. You need to learn how to control your emotions and handle conflicts in a more mature manner. ### Co-workers A: You're right. I'll work on it. But in the meantime, can we talk about something else? Remember when I had to present evidence to support my position in front of a judge? It was so nerve-wracking!' }
